Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Language Acquisition and Language Processing: Finding New Connections

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: A central goal of cognitive science is to understand how the human brain acquires language and uses it to communicate with others. Basic research into understanding human language abilities also holds practical value in areas such as education (where difficulties with language pose a significant barrier for academic and professional success), engagement with social media (where new forms of communication are rapidly developing), and artificial intelligence (where machine learning and other algorithmic methods endow computers with increasingly sophisticated human-language communication). Traditionally, basic research on human language has taken a divide-and-conquer approach, with one part of the research community focused on how children learn languages and the other focused on how adults dynamically comprehend and produce language in real-time. However, exciting new research has bridged this otherwise artificial research divide. Neural and eye-tracking methods have revealed that infants deploy their incomplete understanding of language in real-time, almost as quickly as their adult expert counterparts. Likewise, adults have been found, under specific conditions, to be highly adaptive to language, learning new patterns of speech, new words, and even new syntax from brief exposure. This proposal highlights this new interdisciplinary work and resulting breakthroughs.<br/><br/>The funding will support a special session entitled “Language Acquisition and Language Processing: Finding New Connections” to be held at the 34th Annual CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing (March 4-6, 2021), hosted at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. The session will include presentations from six eminent researchers who bridge language learning and processing, a poster session dedicated to this theme, and travel awards for young student investigators. By bringing researchers studying language acquisition to the premier conference on adult language processing, the session will permit the cross-fertilization of ideas, spawning new important topics of study within human language.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific study of human language abilities has traditionally focused on two central questions. First, how do human infants, when exposed to speech from others, spontaneously learn a complex linguistic system (such as English, Spanish, Japanese) that can express an almost limitless number of ideas and thoughts?  Second, how do adults, who have acquired this complex system, manage to use their knowledge of their language so effortlessly, usually recognizing words within milliseconds and interpreting whole sentences on the fly?  Although these two questions are related, language scientists have traditionally addressed these issues separately, hosting conferences that look primarily at language learning or primarily at language processing. By taking this divide and conquer approach, scientists have learned a great deal about language learning in children and language processing in adults. However, over the last two decades, the distinction between these topics, and their artificial divide in the discipline, have been blurred. Some researchers are now asking how language learning progresses throughout the lifetime into adulthood, and likewise how infants interpret speech in real-time, on the fly, often deploying their incomplete knowledge of the language almost as quickly as their adult expert counterparts. As such, there is now a great need to better integrate theories of language acquisition and language processing.

In recognition of these scientific needs, a special session called “Language Acquisition and Language Processing: Finding New Connections” was held in conjunction with the 34th Annual CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing (March 4-6, 2021), hosted by the University of Pennsylvania. The special session, and the CUNY Conference as a whole, was conducted remotely over the internet due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite this limitation, the special session was a success and had a positive impact on the conference as planned. The six invited speakers presented cutting-edge research through their invited talks. They each bridged the topics of language learning and language processing, from behavioral, neural and computational perspectives. An additional eight main session presentations and fifty-five parallel session presentations were selected based on peer-review to be part of this special session theme. Rather than poster sessions, parallel sessions of short live talks and extended discussion were implemented to better fit the online format of the conference. This was very successful and increased student-faculty interaction significantly.

A total of 1960 individuals registered for the conference, and upwards of 400-500 simultaneously logged in to view presentations and participate in  question-and-answer discussion periods. All presentations were recorded and are now available on youtube and the conference website. Accessibility was a focus, such that closed-captioning and American Sign Language interpretation was provided for plenary sessions. In addition, interactive discussion boards were established for all presentations and are maintained on the conference website.

Finally, a special issue of the journal Language Acquisition has been organized based on this session theme. The special issue is expected to be published late 2022 or early 2023.
